title: In a chapter 7 bankruptcy are credit cards that have cash advances dischargeable.
question: I have over a period of 5 years gotten cash advances or checks from my credit cards. Now our balance is very high. 2 cards at 10k). I sent extra money on a regular basis and didn't know they paid purchases first so the balances never went down. Then they raised the interest to 25%. Used to be 9%.
answers:
I agree with the prior answers. I would like to add that it sounds like the cash advances were old. Just because the credit card agreement sets the order of payment, that does not mean that you had no intent on paying when you took the cash advances out. The payments prove intent to pay. In addition, ability to pay should not be confused with intent to pay.

Having said that, if you intend to file, stop using the cards and consult an attorney now.

New Debt or Transferred Property Just before filing:....BEWARE....
If you make certain charges just before filing bankruptcy cannot be undone in bankruptcy, and may even jeopardize the bankruptcy itself. Here are the most common issues to watch for:

1. Charge of more than $550 in luxury goods or services on any one credit card within 90 days of filing for bankruptcy, the court can presume that you made the charges fraudulently ...that you never intended to repay the credit card company. This would make these charges non-dischargeable and you would still owe them even after the BK discharg...
2. If you run up cash advances totaling $825 or more on any one credit card within 70 days of filing for bankruptcy, the cash advances can be considered fraudulent and can survive your bankruptcy.
3. If you pay more than $600 to a commercial creditor within 90 days of filing for bankruptcy -- or to an 'insider' within a year of filing for bankruptcy, then the bankruptcy trustee can go get it...
4. There is a 2 year period for selling assets for less than market value....good deals to buddies, friend, relatives, neighbors ....and a 10 year look back for financial transactions.

Be very careful and seek advice if you have questions, otherwise you risk the entire process...

There isn't a yes or no answer to your question. Creditors can object to the discharge of any debt, including charges on a credit card, if they can prove that you did not intend, or have a reasonable expectation, of being able to repay the debt at the time it was incurred. Such objections must be brought within 60 days after the first date set for the meeting of creditors in a Chapter 7 case.

The burden of proof is generally on the creditor to prove the fraud (i.e. that the debtor did not intend to repay the debt). However, for cash advances aggregating over $825 for consumer goods taken within 70 days of the filing of the bankruptcy case, the burden of proof shifts to the debtor to prove that they DID intend to repay (which is significantly more difficult to do unless there was an unexpected change of financial circumstances occurring after the charges were made).
